what sort of attacks we can launch on that the main goal is really to to succeed
without having any visible evidence of tampering because most of these people have on them at all times so
or at least they'll leave them at their desk or whatever for a coffee break and that's when an attack can take place so you don't want it to be obvious that
somebody had had tampered with the device it turns out for both of the devices that we talk about
both of them can be opened without any visible evidence of tampering at all and we can
do it with just standard tools exacto knife or screwdriver or whatever so

heat the heat the unit slit one side with an x-acto knife or your fingernail

tokens from an attack point of view is that they usually get scuffed up when they're in people's pockets or thrown around with their keys and whatever so
it it's usually not going to look as nice as a brand new one does so if there's already scuff marks on it and the attacker does make a mistake you
might not notice for the rainbow ikey it's a little bit different scenario where there was no
glue at all and it was still a two-piece housing that was basically held together by

you go you leave your keys or you leave your authentication token uh you go get a cup of coffee you go to

recommendations if you are uh designing these things or if you happen to have them already deployed and you might want to try to retrofit it
one of the recommendations is to have a design that prevents the units from being easily open obviously which
which sometimes is easier said than done but using a sealed or a molded housing in some case
either with ultrasonic welding or high temperature glue will make it a lot harder for somebody to get into and if
they did it would probably be pretty obvious that that something has happened and we'll show an example of this later
on of one authentication token that uh that jeff moss sent me right before the talk
that was sealed it was a one-piece unit sealed ultrasonically so in order to get into it it wasn't as easy as just as
just taking x-acto knife on it so if you use something like that it will be a lot more obvious that an attack has
taken place and if done properly it will require complete destruction of the physical housing in order to get access
to the circuitry so in most instances the attack would not be feasible
using high temperature glue as you saw with the with the aladdin device they did use a glue but it was a
low temperature so it melted when i was using the heat gun um so what i recommend is using a high temperature
glue that will that will not that that the plastic of
the housing will melt before the glue does so that way it will the housing will deform
and it will be obvious that that something has gone wrong there somebody's tampered with it so another thing obviously if you're designing
these or using them consider the service issues that if a legitimate user can open the device which you'd want from a
manufacturing point of view to make it easier for debugging soak in an attacker and if an attacker can get access to the
board then you might have some other problems another suggestion is using some tamper
mechanisms or rather anti-tamper mechanisms i discussed these uh in my previous talk
and there are some notes in the proceedings about it most most of the time using an epoxy encapsulate of some sort some sort of glue over critical
components to protect uh those components from being probed and to prevent an attacker from easily getting access to it and we'll show a picture of
that too and then obfuscating part numbers from the from the actual parts on the board so if the attacker does get
access to the unit it will make it a lot harder for them to reverse engineer the design and figure out what's going on
and in both of these cases as you'll see it took about 20 minutes each to put together a full schematic of the design
and then i could figure out exactly what was going on at that point and that's actually in this section so
once somebody has access to the circuitry is where the real attacks go on um

the same vector of attack which was um reading from from unsecured external memory which
ends up being serial w prompt devices which use two or three wires serial wires
to read and write data to so there's no protection at all um and those devices can be can be read in
circuit so you don't even need to remove the device from the board and you can use it either a standard device programmer or put something together
yourself for five or ten dollars worth of parts just read it through the parallel port
so um in both cases both devices used weak encoding algorithms to protect the pins

the uh all of the pins of the device are underneath the the device they're not you know they're not laid out on the

the hardware there might be other ways that you can attack it in this case i define software attacks
as being non-invasive no physical tampering so this is what i try to look at if i had a sealed device that i didn't want to open
the two goals here for attacks would be to examine the communications between the usb device and the host computer
using like usb snoopy for windows there's probably some linux and mac based tools i don't know i only use
windows unfortunately um and then after snooping the communications see if there's a
possibility to brute force a password out of that uh there are some other attack things but these are the two that we looked at
for these devices way back when when you are monitoring the communication trying to see if there's
any undocumented commands or debug features that could be used to to the attacker's advantage
whether that's basically just seeing how the how the known commands are translated into byte level commands and then just creating new byte level
commands and seeing what happens see how the handling of intentionally
bad packets is with some usb protocol analyzers hardware-based
devices that you can use to monitor communications you can create illegal usb packets so you can just send illegal
type of data to the device and see how it handles it for the most part it will probably handle it because
they're using a cypress device that has this usb module on board so um
you know the the fault really would come down to cypress but either way if it hand if the device handles usb
improperly it might retrieve some sort of data or it might fail in some way that would be beneficial to an attacker
so the the attack process in this case at least in our case of what we did is analyze the typical data transactions
either try to send commands outside of what we regularly see or try to send
